title: Technology enhancements greet Bayonne public school students - NJ.com
text:
Comments 
Approximately 10,000 Bayonne public school students were greeted to a number of advances in technology and curricula as the 2015-16 school year got underway Wednesday. 
Students in the high school social studies classroom will now have access to Chromebooks, and a proposal this year would allow students to bring home the devices in the future. 
"Getting more devices into the students' hands will help the district advance more of its educational goals," said Assistant Superintendent Leo Smith Jr. in a statement. 
Additionally, social studies students in grades 4 and 5 will now have access to electronic textbooks. 
Last year, all students in grades 3 through 8 were afforded access to Chromebooks, and grade 8 students were granted permission to bring the devices home. 
The district will also get Chromebooks into the hands of second graders and a pilot program for tablets will be provided to students in Kindergarten and first grade. 
Software from "Naviance" ― a web-based, college-planning tool used by students, families, teachers and school counselors in middle and high school ― was also purchased. 
Meanwhile, more improvements are being made in the area of physical education and the social studies curricula. 
The kindergarten to 3rd grade social studies curriculum will be revised over the course of the year and teachers will work in small teams to identify the resources that are necessary to help them implement this curriculum. 
"Enhancing our social studies curriculum will offer a wealth of interdisciplinary learning activities for our youngest children, a chance to improve literacy skills and the opportunity to teach them about our wonderful community and our great country," said Superintendent Dr. Patricia McGeehan in a statement. 
All elementary schools will now offer an after-school athletic program for grades 4 and 5. The district will begin with an instructional basketball session, and eventually add track and field, soccer and flag football. 
A youth travel team will also be available for boys and girls grades 7 and 8. 
The Bayonne Board of Education will also launch The Academy for Professional Studies, which partners with New Jersey City University to provide opportunities in areas such as business and technology, and the Career Academy, creating a pathway to a career after graduation. 
Meanwhile, Bayonne High School principal Richard J. Baccarella announced that the school will hold its annual "Back to School Night" on Monday, Sept. 21 from 6 to 8 p.m. During the course of the evening parents and guardians will follow an abbreviated form of their child's schedule. 
Parents and guardians are asked to report to the school's auditorium at 5:30 p.m. There they will be greeted by Baccarella and the administrative staff and will be given a brief overview of life at Bayonne High School. Members of the Bayonne High School Ambassadors Club will then escort the attendees to their child's homeroom. 
During homeroom parents and guardians will be given a copy of their child's schedule, which they will follow throughout the night. 
Back to School Night will be held at the city's elementary schools on Sept. 28, with Nicholas Oresko School holding its Back to School Night on Sept. 29.
